metadata.synopsis: Gale successfully became the god of ambition, and has spent the last six months establishing his domain, seeking new followers, and otherwise acclimatising to godhood. No one has heard from him during that time. His posture/demeanor here should feel slightly more aloof/detached than the regular Gale - he's been immortal for six months, his ego is as powerful as his magic. The real Gale's insecurities still lurk beneath his godlike confidence, as does his love for the player, but this is clearly a Gale setting out on a darker path. He will physically look like a god, and hopefully have some voice processing to add further godliness.

157.speaker: Gale
157.text: You're finding it hard to stay away from me. Perfectly understandable - divine essence has a rather magnetic quality where mortals are concerned.

146.speaker: Gale
146.text: Resist for now, enjoy the night, and I promise - we'll be together soon enough.

172.speaker: Gale
172.text: Goodness. Was Faerûn always so... dull?

9.speaker: Gale
9.text: Still, at least the company was worth the trip, if not the view.

174.speaker: Gale
174.text: It's quite something, isn't it, to be in the presence of the divine.

8.speaker: Gale
8.text: Fear not - that tingling sensation is merely your body's way of alerting you to my presence. It's perfectly harmless. In small doses.

184.speaker: Gale
184.text: A bold decision to treat a divine being with such cold indifference.
184.context: NodeContext: Aloof, annoyed you weren't impressed with him

90.speaker: Gale
90.text: You mortals do love to live dangerously, don't you?
90.context: NodeContext: The slightest hint of a threat - you've probably made an enemy here today, Or at least, you've lost a friend.

200.speaker: Gale
200.text: I hoped I'd see you here.

117.speaker: Gale
117.text: I imagine this must be quite a shock. Whatever you're feeling, do not be afraid. It's still me, just an... improved version.

162.speaker: Player
162.text: I was beginning to think you'd forgotten about me. About your promise...

32.speaker: Player
32.text: So you did it. You became a god?

119.speaker: Gale
119.text: I told you I would, didn't I?

25.speaker: Player
25.text: I thought you were dead. I haven't heard from you in months...

196.speaker: Gale
196.text: I'm afraid time works quite differently in Elysium. I didn't realise how long I'd been gone, until I received Withers' summons.

138.speaker: Player
138.text: Charming. I see godhood's worked wonders on your manners...

69.speaker: Gale
69.text: I'm forgetting my audience. Etiquette amongst the gods works rather differently. They're a lot more... direct, shall we say.

44.speaker: Gale
44.text: I imagine you're wondering how all this came to be. The finer points of divine ascension are beyond mortal comprehension, I'm afraid, but I can provide the rudimentary sequence of events.

179.speaker: Gale
179.text: First, I retrieved the Crown of Karsus, and reforged it using a series of precise and highly-complex Netherese incantations. Then, I used it.

63.speaker: Gale
63.text: As you know, the orb within me was the half-formed Karsite Weave, a magic left incomplete by Karsus's self-destruction.

137.speaker: Gale
137.text: I finished it. Using the Crown of Karsus I turned it into a new form of magic, fused with my being, driven by my purpose. And then I put it to work.

27.speaker: Gale
27.text: As expected, Mystra was unwilling to hand over the reins of the Weave, so I've claimed dominion over another area with which I've passing familiarity: ambition.

165.speaker: Player
165.text: What does the 'God of Ambition' offer to his followers?

190.speaker: Gale
190.text: I 'offer' them nothing. I inspire them to seize their destinies for themselves.

77.speaker: Player
77.text: If that's the criteria for choosing a domain, you should be the God of Wasting Valuable Loot.

103.speaker: Gale
103.text: Mortals and their jokes... I did think to bless the heavens with my own inimitable wit, but alas, most gods are rather devoid of humour.

59.speaker: Gale
59.text: Great as the heights I've reached thus far may be, I've not forgotten my humble origins. In fact, they're central to my doctrine.

121.speaker: Gale
121.text: Those drawn to the Galerian creed don't merely seek my guidance as the impressive, all-powerful being I've become.

37.speaker: Gale
37.text: Ambition is about beginnings. It is not just about the heights, but the lows that preceded them.

183.speaker: Gale
183.text: I was nothing. A drifting dust mote of a wizard, abandoned by my goddess, my powers lost, my reputation destroyed. And look at me now. I'm their proof.

51.speaker: Player
51.text: Where's the Crown of Karsus now?

129.speaker: Gale
129.text: Secure at the heart of my domain, protected by all the powers at my disposal.

113.speaker: Player
113.text: Ambition? Finally, a god I can get behind...

46.speaker: Gale
46.text: I assure you, this is merely the prelude to a far grander vision. Elysium's in for something of a shake-up.

6.speaker: Player
6.text: Ambition? That tends to land people in an early grave. Or a well-deserved coffin, in Cazador's case.

12.speaker: Gale
12.text: Fear not. I'm treading carefully - if you think mortal politics is bad, I assure you - the machinations of the heavens would leave you reeling.

111.speaker: Gale
111.text: I confess, I expected Raphael to come knocking with that infernal contract we signed, but strangely enough he never showed his face. Intimidated, no doubt.

134.speaker: Gale
134.text: I can say this much - for now, Mystra is welcome to her dominion. My aims are set a little higher than offering cursory blessings to just any half-decent spellcaster.
134.context: NodeContext: Hint of scorn - he clearly still thinks badly of Mystra

118.speaker: Gale
118.text: I exist not to bestow favours on my followers, but to inspire them to seize their destinies for themselves, exactly as I did. I'm their proof.

92.speaker: Gale
92.text: Proof their hopes are not barren wastes, but the loamy soil in which their future achievements will flourish. Proof that with ambition, anything is possible.

110.speaker: Player
110.text: You're no different to any other god, letting mortals do all the work.

86.speaker: Gale
86.text: Hardly. I'm simply more honest about my involvement. Not to say I don't help more actively when the cause arises.

80.speaker: Gale
80.text: A whisper in the ear of a struggling artisan. A breeze to flutter the pages of a tome before a frustrated mage. A magical weapon stumbled upon by a desperate would-be hero.
80.context: NodeContext: Describing the ways he's already helped his followers. Very impressed by himself

163.speaker: Player
163.text: Interesting. So you help mortals help themselves?

195.speaker: Gale
195.text: Precisely. Though that isn't to say I'm averse to the odd bit of direct encouragement.

79.speaker: Player
79.text: What of those with evil ambitions? Do you encourage them too?

171.speaker: Gale
171.text: I am the god of ambition, not of the consequences of ambition. Nor am I the arbiter of good or evil, for that matter.

143.speaker: Gale
143.text: At best, those concerned with the consequences of their actions might consult with Savras, god of divination. Though these days, I doubt he'd see them coming.
143.context: NodeContext: Bit of snark at Savras's expense - the god of divination is rarely seen and goes mostly unworshipped

1.speaker: Player
1.text: Your 'ambition' didn't earn you these powers. I did.

91.speaker: Gale
91.text: And while I will be, quite literally, eternally grateful for your assistance, that's not quite the truth.
91.context: NodeContext: Hiding his displeasure - he doesn't like this vision he has of himself being challenged

39.speaker: Gale
39.text: I'm the one who dredged up the Crown, who dared to defy his goddess and claim a place in the heavens. I earned this.

20.speaker: Gale
20.text: I am ambition incarnate. As indistinguishable from that most potent sensation as Mystra herself is from the Weave. And word is spreading.
20.context: NodeContext: Palpable, almost unsettling excitement from him - hint of megalomania

64.speaker: Gale
64.text: There are already several shrines in my honour scattered across the outer reaches of Thay, and rumours of a very prominent temple under construction in Amn.

53.speaker: Player
53.text: For both of us. I'm ready to go with you Gale.

177.speaker: Gale
177.text: I see you won't be claiming the domain of 'patience' in the heavens.

181.speaker: Gale
181.text: All in good time, my love. For now, mortality has one more night of enjoyment in store.

122.speaker: Player
122.text: And what about us? Is there no way we could still be together?

139.speaker: Gale
139.text: I'm sorry, but no. I know what comes of love between the gods and mortals. I would never expose you to such risk.
139.context: NodeContext: Trying to comfort, knows this isn't what you want to hear

124.speaker: Gale
124.text: If I cannot spend an eternity with you, I'll settle for an evening.
124.context: NodeContext: Trying to comfort, knows this isn't what you want to hear

35.speaker: Player
35.text: Then I'll settle for a kiss.

19.context: CinematicNodeContext: Gale and the player share one final kiss. If there's scope - his godly powers are overwhelming for the player, who pulls away as though given an electric shock.

2.context: CinematicNodeContext: Gale and the player share one final kiss. If there's scope - his godly powers are overwhelming for the player, who pulls away as though given an electric shock.

22.speaker: Gale
22.text: You may not wish to enter the heavens, but you do a fine job conjuring them here.
22.context: NodeContext: Gale's final line to the player in the game, in this flow. He still loves them.

130.context: CinematicNodeContext: Gale and the player share one final kiss. If there's scope - his godly powers are overwhelming for the player, who pulls away as though given an electric shock.

199.context: CinematicNodeContext: Gale and the player hug - friendly, sincere. If there's scope - his godly powers are overwhelming for the player, who pulls away as though given an electric shock.

66.context: CinematicNodeContext: Gale and the player hug - friendly, sincere. If there's scope - his godly powers are overwhelming for the player, who pulls away as though given an electric shock.

193.speaker: Gale
193.text: I've found many delights in the heavens so far, but I have to say - nothing as rare as your friendship. It's a fine thing indeed.

98.context: CinematicNodeContext: Gale and the player hug - friendly, sincere. If there's scope - his godly powers are overwhelming for the player, who pulls away as though given an electric shock.

120.context: CinematicNodeContext: Gale and the player hug - friendly, sincere. If there's scope - his godly powers are overwhelming for the player, who pulls away as though given an electric shock.

84.speaker: Player
84.text: What can I say, Gale? I'm impressed.

185.speaker: Gale
185.text: Now, divine as my company undoubtedly is, I've an eternity to catch up with you - a luxury few others at this party possess.

74.speaker: Gale
74.text: Don't let me deprive them of your company. Or mine, for that matter.

135.speaker: Gale
135.text: It's not every day a new-born god shows up to the reunion.
135.context: NodeContext: hint of smugness - thinks he's a hotshot now

38.speaker: Player
38.text: I think it's the end. Of the Gale I knew, at least.

85.speaker: Player
85.text: No, I think it's the end. What happened to the man I once loved?

167.speaker: Gale
167.text: He's the god he deserves to be.

148.speaker: Gale
148.text: I achieved everything we hoped I would, and still I'm not good enough for you?
148.context: NodeContext: Disappointed/frustrated - can't believe he's being judged by you

72.speaker: Gale
72.text: I came here to offer you the heavens, but I see now such an offer would be wasted. I suppose it was foolish to expect a mortal to understand.

194.speaker: Gale
194.text: I believed in you for so much of our journey. It's a pity you won't do me the same courtesy.

36.speaker: Gale
36.text: I suppose it was foolish to expect a mortal to understand.
36.context: NodeContext: disappointed/dismissive - he's drawing a boundary between you

99.speaker: Player
99.text: No, I think it's the end. What happened to the man I loved?

176.speaker: Player
176.text: If you ever need a Chosen, you know where to find me.

131.speaker: Gale
131.text: And renounce your own god? I'm flattered.

102.speaker: Gale
102.text: Pursue your dreams, and keep me in your prayers, and who knows... they might just get answered.

188.speaker: Gale
188.text: Don't worry. With the ambition you hold, you'll never be too far from my sights.

182.speaker: Player
182.text: And do you share this 'Galerian' magic of yours with your followers?

96.speaker: Gale
96.text: Ao would prefer to let the cosmic dust settle from my unexpected ascension before considering my right to grant my followers such power.

114.speaker: Gale
114.text: I'm sure he'll come around, in a millennium or so, and by then my creed will be something to reckon with.

52.speaker: Player
52.text: I understand. A new type of ambition has grown within me, these last months. This illithid form is... powerful.

45.speaker: Gale
45.text: What a twist, to have spent so long thwarting the ambitions of the Illithid Empire, only for me to assist you, a rogue mind flayer, in pursuing yours.

33.speaker: Gale
33.text: Morally dubious? Arguably. But fascinating? Without question. Something to consider...

108.speaker: Gale
108.text: Regardless, ethical quandaries are more the remit of my mortal devotees. They do love to talk, and Faerûn is starting to listen.

126.speaker: Player
126.text: Now you mention it, upholding my oath is challenging when so many flout its tenets. To make all obey its teachings would be... easier.

41.speaker: Gale
41.text: You see? Now you're realising your true potential. You, and many more by the day.

145.speaker: Player
145.text: I couldn't agree more. Mine has carried me far, and is only growing...

0.speaker: Player
0.text: Ambition drove Cazador's cruelty, made him do unspeakable things. You'd really help the likes of him?

132.speaker: Player
132.text: My only ambition is to see Cazador's corpse crumble to dust.

105.speaker: Gale
105.text: But you could be so much more. Trust me - I am ambition incarnate, and like seeks like. I sense it within you, even if you don't.

24.speaker: Gale
24.text: You're not content to fade into the history books just yet. In time, you'll come to see that.

175.speaker: Player
175.text: Any ambition but to serve Lady Shar is a folly. Her eternal darkness shall swallow all dreams, in the end.

149.speaker: Player
149.text: All I want is to live free and go where I please. I can do that all by myself, without any god's intervention.

28.speaker: Player
28.text: My 'ambition' is to have a little cottage, my parents, and a host of animals to keep me company. I've already fulfilled that, without your help.

34.speaker: Player
34.text: My 'ambition' is to have a little cottage, my parents, and a host of animals to keep me company. I've already fulfilled that, without your help.

55.speaker: Player
55.text: My only ambition is to forge my own path, as far from Shar as possible.

87.speaker: Player
87.text: This heart of mine is still an issue. Couldn't a god like you help me out?

154.speaker: Gale
154.text: Yours is a heart I would never let break. But it is not time yet.

15.speaker: Gale
15.text: That infernal contraption of yours has served you well. I think it deserves a good send-off, don't you?

144.speaker: Gale
144.text: Such a feat would certainly be within my capabilities, but alas - my hands are tied. Bodily interference with mortals lies well beyond the purview of my particular niche of divinity.

186.speaker: Gale
186.text: Besides, you know yourself how hot Zariel's bloodlust burns. She'd see the heavens themselves scorched to ash were I to put a spanner in her machinations.

75.speaker: Gale
75.text: That faulty ticker of yours can be fixed, I'm quite certain. But the outcome lies in your hands, not mine. Throw a prayer or two my way, though, and I'll gladly provide some encouragement.

104.speaker: Player
104.text: I'm not in the habit of praying, but I may make an exception for you, Dekarios.

156.speaker: Gale
156.text: A wise decision. Though, if it's all the same to you, I'd suggest making sure your devotions are of the silent variety.

93.speaker: Gale
93.text: Should Zariel catch wind of my greasing your engine, so to speak... well, I suspect neither of us will relish the consequences.

115.speaker: Player
115.text: All a bit airy fairy for a woman with a devil on her scent. Thanks anyway.

150.speaker: Gale
150.text: No use for the god of ambition?
150.context: NodeContext: Bit of an eyebrow raise, not impressed

142.speaker: Gale
142.text: I only hope, once your heart is as strong as your head, you don't regret that decision.

173.speaker: Gale
173.text: Until then, I'll leave you to your own devices. Infernal or otherwise.

112.speaker: Player
112.text: I don't need your kind of proof. I serve the people of Faerûn, not my own ambition.

187.speaker: Player
187.text: I wish to serve the people of Baldur's Gate to the best of my abilities. This is my one and only ambition.

152.speaker: Player
152.text: To protect the Coast from hellspawn is my only ambition. And to that end, I need no god to guide me.

73.speaker: Player
73.text: I already proved the consequences of my ambition - I signed a pact with a devil. It brings nothing good.

180.speaker: Player
180.text: My ambition and my mandate are the same. To destroy Vlaakith, and free my people. If you can aid me, I welcome it.

136.speaker: Player
136.text: My ambitions require no god to aid them. I need no more than my own wiles to slay Vlaakith's assassins.

56.speaker: Player
56.text: I defied my divine fate to live the life I have now. The gods prove nothing to me that I haven't already proven to myself.

81.speaker: Player
81.text: And what might your story prove for a vampire spawn like me? That I too might be able to ascend...

4.speaker: Player
4.text: How far does your power extend? Can you let me walk in the sun again?

107.speaker: Gale
107.text: Why walk in the sun, when you could walk in the heavens themselves?

197.speaker: Gale
197.text: Ask for my blessing in pursuing this ambition, though, and I'll gladly offer what encouragement I can.
197.context: NodeContext: Gale's essentially finding a technicality here - he can't act directly, but if your ambition is powerful enough and you invoke his patronage, he will help you to achieve it.

29.speaker: Player
29.text: I suppose I could spare a prayer or two, for a god willing to listen.

164.speaker: Gale
164.text: Your kin count amongst my most ardent worshippers. Should they feel I see their condition as something to be fixed... well, I imagine they'd make quite a mess of my temples.
164.context: NodeContext: Leaning in/ hint of conspiracy

10.speaker: Player
10.text: So I do all the work, and you take all the credit? No, I'll do it myself.

88.speaker: Gale
88.text: Your kin certainly don't see things that way - their zeal for my doctrine is quite unparallelled.

42.speaker: Gale
42.text: I can't imagine what they'd do to someone threatening to cure them. But I'm sure you can do that without my help as well.
42.context: NodeContext: Feigning politeness but huffy - implying his vampire followers might try to prevent you finding the cure, and that he won't do much to help you.

189.speaker: Player
189.text: You're welcome to them. Mystra has no need of such followers, nor their 'ambitions.'

49.speaker: Player
49.text: Ambition? Finally, a god I can get behind...

78.speaker: Player
78.text: So long as you're aware that all domains shall be consumed by Lady Shar, in the end. Until then, enjoy it.

21.speaker: Player
21.text: Interesting. If the chance should arise for you to thwart Shar in some way, assume you have my support.

11.speaker: Player
11.text: Interesting. If the chance should arise for you to thwart Shar in some way, assume you have my support.

128.speaker: Player
128.text: Interesting. If the chance should arise for you to thwart Shar in some way, assume you have my support.

158.speaker: Player
158.text: Seems you've found your true calling. I envy you.

153.speaker: Player
153.text: Just don't go starting any fights up there. It's bad enough down below.

155.speaker: Player
155.text: Ambition hews close to hubris, Gale. I hope for all our sake that you don't confuse them.

100.speaker: Player
100.text: So long as your ambitions serve to help mortals, and not harm them, I'm happy for you.

70.speaker: Player
70.text: My people were once sacrificed on the altar of Vlaakith's ambition. It is a dangerous path to follow.

83.speaker: Player
83.text: More of the petty squabbles of gods. Your ambitions will make you as gormless as all the others.

14.speaker: Player
14.text: Would you mind demolishing Bhaal's domain while you're at it? Just if you're passing through.

17.speaker: Player
17.text: So you gave up on dethroning Mystra? Doesn't sound so ambitious to me.

192.speaker: Gale
192.text: I don't recall saying that I'd given up.
192.context: NodeContext: Awkwardly clearing his throat - torn between the need to refute your accusation, and knowing that doing so would be a terrible, terrible idea

94.speaker: Player
94.text: So you gave up on dethroning Mystra? Doesn't sound so ambitious to me.

127.speaker: Player
127.text: Your presence, it sets my teeth on edge. Is this the power of Karsus at work?

201.speaker: Gale
201.text: Not to be overly pedantic, but they are my powers now.

147.speaker: Player
147.text: Your presence, it sets my teeth on edge. Is this the power of Karsus at work?
